name: Marvin Gaye
description:
'''Marvin Pentz Gaye Jr.''' ({{ne|'''Gay'''}}; April 2, 1939 – April 1, 1984){{sfn|Simmonds|2008|pp=190–192}} was an American singer, songwriter, musician and record producer. Commonly referred to as the [[Honorific nicknames in popular music#G|"Prince of Motown" and "Prince of Soul"]], he helped to shape the sound of [[Motown]] and [[soul music]] in the 1960s. A [[cultural icon]], Gaye is often considered one of the [[Rolling Stone's 200 Greatest Singers of All Time|greatest singers]] and [[Rolling Stone's 100 Greatest Songwriters of All Time|songwriters]] of all time.

Born and raised in Washington, D.C., Gaye began his career being guided by [[Harvey Fuqua]], who put him in his group, [[The Moonglows|Harvey and the Moonglows]], before Gaye ventured into a solo career at the beginning of the 1960s. Signing to Motown's Tamla subsidiary, he achieved stardom with a series of hit singles such as "[[How Sweet It Is (to Be Loved by You)]]", "[[Ain't That Peculiar]]" and "[[I Heard It Through the Grapevine]]" and also earned success as a collaborative duet partner with several female artists, most notably, [[Diana Ross]] and [[Tammi Terrell]], the latter of whom he recorded the hits "[[Ain't No Mountain High Enough]]" and "[[You're All I Need to Get By]]". Following the successful release of his landmark album, ''[[What's Going On (album)|What's Going On]]'' and its [[What's Going On (song)|hit of the same name]], in 1971, Gaye became one of the first Motown artists to break away from the reins of a production company, later producing the albums, ''[[Let's Get It On]]'', ''[[I Want You (Marvin Gaye album)|I Want You]]'' and ''[[Here, My Dear]]''.

After a period as a [[tax exile]] in Europe and leaving Motown for [[Columbia Records]] in 1982, Gaye re-emerged that year with "[[Sexual Healing]]" and its album, ''[[Midnight Love]]'', which became his most successful single and album respectively to date and performed a memorable rendition of "[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]" at the [[1983 NBA All-Star Game]].{{sfn|Batchelor|2005|pp=41–43}} The success of "Sexual Healing" led to Gaye winning an [[American Music Award]] and two [[Grammy Awards]].

On April 1, 1984, Gaye was [[Killing of Marvin Gaye|shot and killed]] by his father, [[Marvin Gay Sr.]] at his parents' house in [[Western Heights, Los Angeles|Western Heights]], Los Angeles on the eve of his 45th birthday. Gay Sr. later pleaded [[no contest]] to [[voluntary manslaughter]], receiving a six-year suspended sentence and five years of probation.

In addition to 1960s soul music, Gaye also influenced 1970s soul music and his recordings of that era later influenced the R&B subgenres [[quiet storm]] and [[neo soul]]. Several of his hit singles and albums have made several best-of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' lists, including its [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Albums of All Time|greatest albums]] and [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Songs of All Time|greatest songs]] of all time.

In addition to the two Grammys and American Music Award, Gaye's [[List of awards and nominations received by Marvin Gaye|accolades]] include the [[Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award]], a [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] star and inductions into the [[NAACP Image Award – Hall of Fame Award|NAACP Hall of Fame]], [[National Rhythm and Blues Hall of Fame]], [[Songwriters Hall of Fame]] and the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]].
